President Steven Muller
announced plans Wednesday to
set up a board to review the
University's corporate
investments with emphasis on
Hopkins' "social responsibility."
Muller's announcement came
in response to a list of demands
presented on Monday by black
administrators, faculty and
students at Hopkins. The focus
of the demands centered around
the University's interests in
companies involved in South
Africa and called for a group to
review Hopkins' social
responsibility in corporate
involvement.
In his statement Muller
indicated that the group will have
student and black representation
but refused to be influenced by
demands concerning the make-up

of the review board.
Muller said that "the
University is prepared to examine
corporate involvement" and that
he is willing to consult with other
universities on the issue as
recommended in the list of
demands. However, he refused to
set the August 15 deadline for a
conference of major private
universities on corporate
involvement to be held at
Hopkins as suggested in the
blacks' statement.

asserted that he would not
"attempt to dictate *to other
universities how they should be
represented in any process of
joint discussion." The demands

representatives from each of the
universities attending the

proposed conference.

like to receive a list of businesses
involved in South Africa from
the new review board.

percent pleased with the
decision. We are surprised at the
speed with which President
Muller answered the demands."
Holmes said that he and his
group are still pressing for the
conference on corporate
involvement.

black statement was aimed at
Hopkins' investments in Gulf Oil

New Lit course to have nine profs
A survey course which
includes works by Virgil through
Virginia Wolfe will be offered
next semester as the first move in
the creation of a program in
comparative western literature.
The course, entitled "Man and
His Fictions: Forms of Narrative
in Western Literature," will be
coordinated by Dr. Richard
Macksey, Humanities Center, and
will be taught by at least nine
different professors.
Dean George Owen announced
the plans for the development of
this program last Friday. He
explained that he will chair the
cooperative effort of the five
departments who have already
commited themselves to the
program.
Macksey commented, "I don't
see a department of comparative
literature, rather we should have.
permeable walls. I'd like to see

some joint appointments and a
good deal of cooperation." Owen
said that some expansion of the
facylty will be needed, but he
doesn't expect it to expand
unreasonably.
According to Owen,
department chairman from
English, German, Spanish,
French Humanities Center and
Classics will all sit in as a
committee to organize work in
this program. A representative
from Near Eastern Studies will
also be asked to join in the
group, said Macksey.
For the course next year, the
only one that will deal with
comparative western literature
for the first semester, faculty
from each of these groups will
handle a portion of the class
lectures. "Right now everyone in
the program is senior faculty, but
I anticipate that there ought to

be a greater mix of juniors and
senior faculty," said Macksey.
The course next semester will
focus on works in translation
with men lecturing on their
specialities and special attention
should be given to the different
critical methods used in these
specialties. "A course like this
can't just be a lyceum where
people come in to lecture. There
has to be some sort of
continuity. The course will be a
bus ride through western
literature with me as the
moderator," said Macksey.
Macksey maintains that he is
getting advice on how to plan the
course from all corners, and he
calls that a good sign for the
future of the program. He
pointed out that he will use some
films for parts of the course,
using Fellini Satyicon when the
students are reading Petronius'

work,for example.
"We will keep it to a lower
level course to invite people from
areas other than literature to
become involved," said Macksey.

Seniors find market tight
By HOWARD SIMONS
The outlook for seniors
searching for jobs is only slightly
better this year than it was last
year, according to Placement
Bureau director Mrs. Marilyn
Bugg.
"This year's senior class is
having a tough time lining up
work," explained Bugg, "because
there are 816,000 graduating
students this year nationwide,
and the opportunities are
scarce." The hardest hit, she
explained, are liberal arts majors,
"75 percent of students in this
country are liberal arts majors.
Personnel men used to be willing
to hire them, and then train them
for specific jobs. Companies can
no longer afford to do this."
Liberal arts majors are not the

only ones suffering, however.
Applicants to medical school
have to face 20-1 odds on their
chances for admission, not to
mention the time and expense of
completing the applications.
Other grad school applicants are
finding their chances getting
progressively slimmer as well.
Surprised
"I'm really surprised by the
number of applicants to law
school," stated Bugg. "There are
now four times as many law
school applicants as there are
business school applicants
nationwide." She cited the
relative glamour of being a
lawyer as one of the reasons for
the huge increase in law school
application, which used to be on
a level with business applications.

One factor that has hurt job
seekers is the fact that there has
been a freeze on government
hiring, which formerly was a
huge source of employment for
recent graduates. Particularly
hurt are engineering, math, and
liberal arts majors. Said Bugg,
"The government situation
should improve with the coming
of the new fiscal year."
The duties of the Placement
Bureau at Hopkins are different
than those of other schools, Bugg
explained, because about 50
percent of the graduating class
goes on to graduate school, and
consequently do not have to look
for jobs. The Bureau is willing to
help prospective graduate
students as well as other
students.

Masi is a traditional art form in the Fiji
Islands, where Gale taught school in
1970. Known in other parts of the Pacific
as Tapa Cloth, masi comes from the
smooth inner bark of the paper mulberry
tree. The intricate design motifs which
characterize Fijian masi have deep
cultural significance for the islanders.
Gale's own collection of masi is on
display in the lobby of the Eisenhower
Library until May 14.

The paper mulberry tree (Broussonetia
Papyrifera) is cultivated by Fijian men in
small plantations, and cut down when it
reaches maturity, at which point it is
twelve feet high, with a trunk only several
inches in circumference. The bark is
separated from the tree by soaking, and
then beaten flat on a log. A strip of bark
only two inches wide can be beaten out
to a width of two feet. Finished pieces
are united to form great sheets of bark
cloth many yards in length and width.
After masi is dried in the sun, it can be
marked, stencilled, stained or painted
using dyes from other Fijian trees.
Originally used as clothing, masi came
to be a sacred part of Fijian community
life. It had the distinction of being the
clothing of the gods as well, and thus
received the highest place of honor in the
ceremonies of birth, puberty, marriage,
death, and most important, the
installation of a chief. Masi was also used
in Fijian houses to provide partitions for
privacy, and as an article of formal barter
or exchange.

By HOWARD SIMONS
The outlook for seniors
searching for jobs is only slightly
better this year than it was last
year, according to Placement
Bureau director Mrs. Marilyn
Bugg.
"This year's senior class is
having a tough time lining up
work," explained Bugg, "because
there are 816,000 graduating
students this year nationwide,
and the opportunities are
scarce." The hardest hit, she
explained, are liberal arts majors,
"75 percent of students in this
country are liberal arts majors.
Personnel men used to be willing
to hire them, and then train them
for specific jobs. Companies can
no longer afford to do this."
Liberal arts majors are not the

only ones suffering, however.
Applicants to medical school
have to face 20-1 odds on their
chances for admission, not to
mention the time and expense of
completing the applications.
Other grad school applicants are
finding their chances getting
progressively slimmer as well.
Surprised
"I'm really surprised by the
number of applicants to law
school," stated Bugg. "There are
now four times as many law
school applicants as there are
business school applicants
nationwide." She cited the
relative glamour of being a
lawyer as one of the reasons for
the huge increase in law school
application, which used to be on
a level with business applications.

One factor that has hurt job
seekers is the fact that there has
been a freeze on government
hiring, which formerly was a
huge source of employment for
recent graduates. Particularly
hurt are engineering, math, and
liberal arts majors. Said Bugg,
"The government situation
should improve with the coming
of the new fiscal year."
The duties of the Placement
Bureau at Hopkins are different
than those of other schools, Bugg
explained, because about 50
percent of the graduating class
goes on to graduate school, and
consequently do not have to look
for jobs. The Bureau is willing to
help prospective graduate
students as well as other
students.

Masi is a traditional art form in the Fiji
Islands, where Gale taught school in
1970. Known in other parts of the Pacific
as Tapa Cloth, masi comes from the
smooth inner bark of the paper mulberry
tree. The intricate design motifs which
characterize Fijian masi have deep
cultural significance for the islanders.
Gale's own collection of masi is on
display in the lobby of the Eisenhower
Library until May 14.

The paper mulberry tree (Broussonetia
Papyrifera) is cultivated by Fijian men in
small plantations, and cut down when it
reaches maturity, at which point it is
twelve feet high, with a trunk only several
inches in circumference. The bark is
separated from the tree by soaking, and
then beaten flat on a log. A strip of bark
only two inches wide can be beaten out
to a width of two feet. Finished pieces
are united to form great sheets of bark
cloth many yards in length and width.
After masi is dried in the sun, it can be
marked, stencilled, stained or painted
using dyes from other Fijian trees.
Originally used as clothing, masi came
to be a sacred part of Fijian community
life. It had the distinction of being the
clothing of the gods as well, and thus
received the highest place of honor in the
ceremonies of birth, puberty, marriage,
death, and most important, the
installation of a chief. Masi was also used
in Fijian houses to provide partitions for
privacy, and as an article of formal barter
or exchange.

In this sports-minded society
of ours, where grown men earn
staggering sums to take part in

too easy to deify the athletes
whose names dominate the pages
of countless newspapers and
sporting magazines throughout
the land.
The superstars seem to acquire
an aura of holiness, a special
invincibility that sets them apart
from us mere mortals who were
never destined to perform in the
huge stadia that populate every
metropolitan area.
It was thus a most pleasant
surprise and a welcome
opportunity to receive an
invitation from the Orioles to a
press conference for local high
school and college sports editors.
As it turned out, it was a most
enlightening occasion as well.
Close Range
After Ed Brethauer and I were
ushered to the conference room,
in walked outfielders Don Buford
and Mery Rettenmund, dressed
of course in their sparkling clean
uniforms with "orioles"
emblazoned in orange across the
front, but there was something
different this time. Instead of
being so far away, these two
major leaguers were at close
range, where I could verify that
they looked just like anyone else.
More importantly, it was obvious
that these guys were human,
personable fellows, and a joy to

chat with.
The press conference centered
around the ballplayers' personal
lives, and the joys and problems
of playing baseball for a living.
One special problem inherent
in a ballplayer's profession is the
strain on his family life from
being away from home so often.
In Merv's words, "I spend more
time away from home than I do
at home. For a number of
reasons I played winter ball, and
now I have a lot of speaking
engagements for the club. It's a
strain on family life year round."

While on the road, the players
adapt to the peculiar schedule
imposed on them by night games.
After a game, the guys go back to
the room to watch TV until it
goes off the air, around four.
They sleep till one, eat a light
lunch, and then catch a movie
before going to the park.
Of the other eleven American
League cities, both Rettenmund
and Buford laughed out
"Cleveland!" in unison when
asked which was the dullest. As
for the most exciting place to
visit, New York was rated at the
top, as well as Oakland and Los
Angeles.

if there was any truth to Jim
Bouton's claims of players using
drugs. Rettenmund didn't deny
it. "Bouton, in his book, named
Detroit and Baltimore as the
teams that used the most drugs.

There's some truth to it, because
that year (1970) the Tigers and
the Orioles were the main

Negotiations between
commercial airlines and airport
authorities on the proposed sale
of Baltimore-owned Friendship
International Airport to
Maryland have bogged down on
the question of who will pay
airport modernization and
renovation costs.
Both airline officials and the
Friendship International Airport
Authority have blamed each
other for failing to shoulder the
financial burden of the proposed
$15 to $20 million airport
modernization.

Robert L. Scott, Eastern

the negotiating committee for all
commercial airlines involved,
recently attacked the present

them $56 million," he said,
"That $1.4 million should have
been plowed right back into the
airport."
Dragging Feet
Representing the airport,
William Adelson, chairman of the
Friendship International Airport
Authority accused the
commercial airlines of "dragging
their feet" in negotiations over
financing Friendship's
modernization because of the
possibility of a state takeover of
the airport.
If the state does buy the
airport from Baltimore City for
an agreed price of $26 million in
bonds and an estimated $14.6
million in interest payments, the
commercial airlines will win their
two year battle to stop
underwriting Friendship's $1.4
million-a-year rental costs and
may avoid paying for airport
renovations by refusing to pay
increased airport fees.
If the sale does take place, and
the airlines decide not to
cooperate on modernization
financing, the State of Maryland
will have to pay for airport
improvements with money
obtained from the state gasoline
tax which makes up the bulk of
Maryland's Consolidated
Transportation Fund.
Lose Money

help fund the needed airport
improvements, the sale of the
city-owned airport to the state
will cost the Maryland public $50
million in property taxes.
